text: Another common place that we use the mood tense in Spanish is when we say it is an adjective, que, and then a verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This verb is going to go into the mood tense.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You are noticing that que has a lot to do with the subjunctive, that this que introduces the mood tense in many cases.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, if I want to give you some advice and tell you it's terrible that you eat this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It is terrible that you eat this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So let's speak informally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Es terrible que comas esto.

text: Good.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Es terrible que comas esto.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's the que, the combination of es terrible and que, which introduces this mood tense.

text: If you say it is terrible if you eat this, then you don't use the mood tense.

text: In English we achieve a similar feeling to what we get with the Spanish subjunctive, sometimes with words like should or might.
